awd_titl_txt: SCC-PG: Using Innovations in Sensing, Data Analytics, and Community Engagement to Address Opioid Overdose Crisis
awd_abstract_narration:
Opioid overdose is now the leading cause of death for those under 50 in the USA. Cities have followed different strategies to address this problem through various education/training programs. However, the growing scale of the opioid overdose crisis in the USA indicates that more effective data-driven approaches are needed. Opioid abuse and overdose have been identified as a leading method of premature death in the Richmond Region, Virginia. Inadequate data is a major issue for city officials, which prevents them from investigating the scale of the opioid epidemic. Since locality’s economic competitiveness and their ability to recruit businesses and labor are dependent on the image they portray, the data sharing and further analytics in opioid overdoses have seen limited improvement. To this end, this planning project proposes to build a team of researchers and local stakeholders - including those in the leadership roles in all cities and counties in the Richmond Region. The team will work towards a data-driven understanding of the problem and community-involved solutions to address the issue. As responses to the opioid problem are common to other metro regions in the U.S., we hope to scale the model to be exercised in other regions. This project aims to harness the power of data analytics and smart technologies to develop creative solutions for efficient decision-making and planning to improve public health and living standards. Direct broader impacts include evidence-based factors that enhance and impair community responses to the opioid epidemic that can be discussed and refined with community members to drive change, and accordingly, reduce opioid overdose and health inequities across the region.

From the technical perspectives, this project will investigate novel data-driven approaches to treatment policies that can be supported by the community. The intellectual merit of this work includes: (1) developing a fundamental understanding of challenges facing communities due to opioid epidemics, (2) developing a better understanding of the relationship between governance, smart cities, and social innovation, particularly for addressing the opioid problem, (3) collecting relevant types of drug use data in the community, (4) deriving prediction models based on the available data from different sources, and (5) developing smart sensing solutions to accurately monitor and assess the state of drug abuse. Accordingly, this project aims to establish interdisciplinary efforts to develop a data-driven intervention in addressing the opioid overdose crisis, in coordination with community representatives to identify and assess applicable approaches. The team will investigate several predictive models for forecasting drug use/overdoses by considering diverse data on drug-related incidents. The project will also investigate Explainable Machine Learning techniques that will be coupled with developed data-driven models in order to provide estimations of drug use with an explanation of the important factors that justify the predictions made by the model. This will help identify the root causes and the extent of their impact.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Drug overdose is now the leading cause of death for those under 50 in the United States. In this project, we focus on the ongoing opioid crisis in the Greater Richmond Region and we restrict our data to those related to opioid morbidity and mortality. This planning project seeks to establish interdisciplinary efforts and assemble a core group of scientists from different units of Virginia Commonwealth University (VCU), including Engineering, Government and Public Affairs, School of Medicine, and Institute for Drug and Alcohol Studies at VCU, to develop a data-driven intervention in addressing the opioid overdose crisis, in coordination with city administrators and community representatives to identify and assess the potentially applicable approaches in the Greater Richmond Area.

In this project we investigated novel methodologies for collecting, managing and analyzing more diverse data of illicit drug use and overdoses to assist communities and city planners in addressing the ongoing opioid problem through (1) developing a fundamental understanding of challenges facing communities due to opioid as well as prescription opioid use usage and overdoses, (2) developing a better understanding of the relationship between governance, smart cities, and social innovation, particularly for addressing the opioid problem, (3) collecting relevant types of drug use data in the community, (4) deriving prediction models based on the available data from different sources, and (5) developing smart sensing solutions to accurately monitor and assess the state of drug abuse.

The team discussed and investigated the idea of implementing the wastewater epidemiology platform with representatives from the City of Richmond. Sewage-based drug epidemiology methods could offer additional insights into the burden of opioid use. To identify the highest risk communities in Richmond for opioid use and mortality, which can serve as sewage sampling sites, we utilized methods previously developed by the VCU Department of Family Medicine and Population Health to compare actual and predicted opioid mortality. This model incorporated data from the Virginia All-Payer Claims Database, Virginia Department of Health (VDH) statewide medical examiner registry, and American Community Survey (ACS). Data was converted to the Zip Code Tabulation Area (ZCTA). Our team built on this model in order to identify ?Cold Spot? communities in Richmond, communities with higher mortality than would be predicted based on community-level risk factors, and ?Bright Spot? communities in Richmond, communities with lower opioid mortality than would be predicted based on their risk factors. We performed a Residuals Analysis, which enabled the calculation of the differences between predicted output from the multivariate model (predicted mortality), and known measured value (known fatal opioid mortality, as reported by the VDH). The following are the key finding of this study:  

● Three communities have consistently worse outcomes: Several communities consistently have higher mortality than would be predicted based on their local risk factors, when reviewing data for years 2016-2019. These communities also have the highest magnitude of Cold Spot (i.e., much higher mortality than predicted).

● Nearly every community in the Greater Richmond area is a Cold Spot: Our statistical model was developed using data across the Commonwealth of Virginia. When a localized analysis is performed of the Richmond Greater area, it appears that 18 of 20 communities with data available are considered Cold Spots, with higher mortality than predicted.

● Recommended sewage testing sites: Six sites are commended for sewage sampling. These communities were selected to provide a mixture of Bright and Cold Spots, as well as to test in communities with the highest actual mortality compared to predicted.

● Community with positive outcomes had highest primary care visit rate.

● New challenges due to the COVID-19 pandemic: During our collaborative meetings, we discussed how opioid overdoses have increased significantly during the COVID-19 pandemic with the majority of patients being from underserved minority backgrounds.

Direct broader impacts of this project include introducing evidence-based factors that enhance and impair community responses to the opioid epidemic. These factors can be discussed and refined with community members to drive change, and accordingly, reduce opioid overdose and health inequities across the region. Through analyzing opioid data, trends and geographic ?hotspots? can be identified. This data will also be helpful for medical workers and police to track and map drug overdoses, so they can determine new treatment policies to be ready in high-risk neighborhoods in stemming the tide of opioid-related death. The project demonstrated that a transformative advance in tools, techniques and strategies can help city planners and health officials to address the opioid problem more efficiently and effectively.
